There are 20+ downvotes from people OUTSIDE the U.S, simply because they cannot play NA Lost Saga, despite there being EU Lost Saga, IN, Korean, and even South American. The reason for the block is lag issues, this being a fighting game, lag from people across the globe will break gameplay.

Anyway, this is a great game, taking fighters for KoF, BlazBlue, and from Asian manga series. You have the capability to switch fighters at any time, equip gears found from other fighters onto your own for skill customization, which thus creates endless combo possibilities (sometimes a bit too much). There's PvP, PvE, Plazas, and HQ's, where you can invite friends in all cases. There's an in game market system akin to Steam's own, where you can buy other people's gears and sell your own, (even comes with taxes!).

Just, just try it.

I've been with this game since it launched into the stages of Open Beta Testing with OGP, so around 5 years now. And over that time, I've watched the game evolve and flourish. Yes, there's been some missteps, but we're here, and the game is at it's best, the best it's been in a long time.

For starters, our current hosts, Z8Games, have given players the most stuff our of all three publishers (OGPlanet and WeMadeUSA being the other two). Z8Games regularly gives out chances to get style packages (let's you completely style out a hero regardless of style level restrictions. It also let's you choose to have the female gender). We also just today had a perm hero scroll in the attendance calendar, which gives a player a random permanent hero!

We also had a large game changing update recently that made the game a lot more newbie friendly. the first quest you do now gives you a scroll that lets you choose a permanenet hero of CHOICE out of a selection of heroes. Master modes of dungeons ALSO now give perm hero scrolls as drops, which means even more chances at free permanent heroes!

Now, onto the part I'm sure you're wondering about. Is the game pay2win? With the current state of the game, I can honestly say it is not. With all the free stuff being given, a free player can get a lot of permanent stuff, as well as GOOD permanent stuff. I myself have gotten 18 free permanent heroes, and then paid for one (a premium, only available with cash). Now, while premiums and rares might only be available through cash, that doesn't make the game pay2win. Some of them are outright bad, and some of the better ones have a free hero that's as good as that rare or premium hero, so you can still compete.

All that said, I give this game my full seal of approval. I say give the game a shot. If you don't like it, chances are it just wasn't meant for you. After all, not all fighting games appeal to everyone. However, be considerate of others if you review the game. Even if you didn't enjoy it, others might as well.

reviewText:
I actually hate typing this out, because I had such -high- hopes for Lost Saga hitting Steam. But...I can't recommend this to anyone, veterans or newbies, on account of several issues, major and minor.

Firstly, that this can be seen on non-North American Steam storefronts is -very- bad, as several have already experienced region locks. If TERA can have a European page for so very long, while it's North American counterpart never had one until last month or so, Lost Saga can be taken down from the non-NA Steam storefronts. That should be a simple matter of contacting Valve and asking it to be done.

Secondly, anyone who had played Lost Saga before and were hoping they could get playing again via Steam can drop those thoughts right now. You can only link new accounts to Steam, not old accounts. The reason they give for this is mostly bull, something about technical issues, but most Free to Play games here on Steam freely have linking, allowing new and old players alike to log on to their accounts using the Steam version of their launchers and clients. Why can't the same be done here? Just having this -not- be a thing is a detriment to the game.

Thirdly, if you have your computer set to Japanese locale, you can't play the game. Period. AppLocale won't work either. I don't know the reason for this. X-Trap, the anti-cheat software used in Lost Saga, detects your locale and if it isn't set to English, it locks you out of the game. This makes zero sense. Why would it lock you out of playing the game for having Japanese locale? Some games here on Steam require the locale to be set to Japanese to function properly, and all of them run in English locale as well (though with issues) instead of locking you out of the game. There is -no excuse- for having X-Trap locking you out of Lost Saga, and considering the wide array of games available on Steam, having one that explicitly locks you out of the game is a -very- stupid move.

As for the cash shop, it's quite bad. I don't know about pay to win, since there are usually enough events going on throughout the year to throw free stuff at people, but the cash shop could be better than it is right now. But the serious issues are the above three.

If you are interested in playing, you need to take real care to make sure that your locale is set to English, and that you are a brand new player. If you are a veteran, don't bother touching the Steam version since you can't use your account on it. If you are in a region-locked area, I'm sorry that the game being shown in your area is teasing you (though really, it says NA right in the title, use your eyes), and I'm hoping that can get rectified.

Smilegate, this is a disgraceful way to launch the game on Steam. The X-Trap issue has been known ever since the game launched under Z8Games, and it was never addressed even up until now? And now that the game is on Steam, you have the gall to alienate us veteran players by not allowing us to use our old accounts on Steam? I had such high hopes for coming back after this hit Steam, but now I'm just disappointed. Very disappointed.

Before I go into the specifics I'm just going to say this flat out: The game is ♥♥♥, no question about it.

Here's the thing, I've played this game since OGP; even beta'd it with my friend before it even came out. I spent literally years lying to myself about how great the game was. I just quit recently because after all this time I got fed up with it.

Here's why:

1. Pay to win: You must throw your wallet at the screen to be even competitive in this game. While I played, my main was the Dark Shaman and it was a low tier character I completely dominated with. Main reason is that I had to buy certain gears to keep him viable as the game devolved into a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ basicly money only game. The main people I see voting for this game are most likely people fine with this aspect and have already spent a ton of money. To them, there's no point in quitting since they've already invested a large amount of funds in this product.

2. There's no point in the characters this game showcases. You could easily just make an avatar and outfit him or her with whatever style or gameplay you choose. You want a magic character, give him a staff, you want a ninja, pick the kunai, and etc. If they had made the game to where you couldn't interchange different character gear and only able to use gear you bought, the game would be perfectly fine. But guess what, you can; making the point of having such characters moot and pointless.

3. The game seems to force you to pvp. Reasons:
a. Lags like hell during crusade and other pve modes.
b. exp gain is slow compared to playing with someone for a couple of hours.
c. The difficulty in Adventure mode is unbalanced to where the only way you get a somewhat adequate exp gain is to do Master with a bunch of people.
d. Party with people at your own risk. If you don't play with friends, you may get leeches that hang back while you fight everything. It's just not worth it in the greater scheme of things.

4. If you aren't a veteran, you're pretty much screwed. The main reason is that certain gears people own showcase an incredibly OP ability that's either hard to dodge or difficult to counter. You're also faced with people with stats in the 100s in which you can only beat by some obscure tactic that involves a gear you missed out on. The thing is, if they hadn't dragged their feet on getting this game to steam, this problem probably wouldn't be that bad. Coupled with the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ room rank finding system, new players would run before they sat around long enough to dig their heels into the experience and just roll with it.

5. ♥♥♥♥♥♥ community. 9 times out of 10 you will come across a shitbird that has his ego so far up his ♥♥♥ that he believes he can beat anyone and raises a complete ruckus wherever he goes. I was however, helpful and nice to newer players and took it easy. The fact still remains though, that there are people like me and people much worse than me.

About 90% of the rooms you'll see in the queue are farm rooms. Anyone that states otherwise is full of crap. Even the people that have put more time into leveling their characters than I, farm their asses off to do so. In that sense, there's not really much accomplishment.

7. Slow leveling. One actually has to fight at least 8 hours out of a day and win the majority of his matches in a large room to make headway once you get past lvl 30. If you don't want to do this, you can sade or adventure with possibly unreliable people or you can just fish. This is the slowest leveling method of all.

8. Premium characters: Iori, Kyo, Mai, and Project K are probably the characters that you'll encounter most when playing other people including the veterans. Along with Staff Master and Destroyer, all 6 of these characters make the game even more pay 2 win. You can literally, I mean literally throw your face in the keyboard and win these characters. Which once again, makes the game even more pay2win since 4 are premium and 2 you can buy to bypass the rank restriction.

9. The events are crap. Sure, you get certain things to sort of catch to those that have been playing forever, but these events are far in between the instances where they update the shop with new gear everyone runs out to buy.

All in all, I put myself through a lot with this game. I had a total of about 60+ characters and 200-300+ pieces of gear in this game. reviewText:
There was a time when I would have, and did frequently, recommend this game to everyone that played games. I was happy to play it, I was always excited when there was an update, and any time I encountered a problem, I was quick to find the bright side and even come back later. I held four accounts over the years and passes between companies and servers, and I had numerous heroes and gears, some rare and hard to get. Every little part of this game made me happy.

However, that has all come to a slow, painful, depressing stop. It started when I was first ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off by the original owners all but dropping the game on this side of the world. However, it passed. I brushed myself off with no troubles and simply resolved that it merely wasn't meant to be. I was even overjoyed when I heard that it was picked up again, and I was one of the first to sign up for the new one. Even having to make a completely new profile because of a foolish and easily rectifiable error by the company only gave me momentary pause. I was just happy to play again. But that's where it started to feel a little stale. Well, the game continued to fall down in the world's eyes, even to the point of the US server being excluded from an international tournament. That was when I first questioned how much I really loved this game. Still, I loved what it was, and I especially loved what it still had the potential to be. And when it lost this new carrier, I was mortified. I remember actually being depressed about it for a while. As you can imagine, this kind of embittered me to mmo's in general, and I fell out of a lot at the time. Well, it was with that still-bitter eye that I noticed the game had been passed off again. By this time, I was less than convinced that it would last, and so I entered in again with full intentions of not getting attached so I wouldn't care as much when it was inevitably abandoned again, but I always held out that hope that it wouldn't. Surprise surprise, it was axed again. Very unceremoniously this time, too. I'd given up on it by this point, so when I found out that the game had been put out on Steam, I was actually pleasantly surprised, and believed this meant it was for once here to stay. I jumped back in and played along, even enjoying all the new features and events.

And you know what? The game is still fun. It is unique and fun to play, and the concept is still pretty novel, as far as I'm concerned. I'd even agree that the pay to win model is fixable with hard work, dedication, and lots of effort.

So if I still like the game, why's this review negative? Simple:

The community is one of the most toxic I have ever experienced in my life, and the people in charge of the game do absolutely nothing about it. The best there is to deal with it is a block feature that does nothing before a match except keep you, and only you by the way, from reading anything they type, and a poorly made censor that messes up perfectly reasonable words because it looks for a sequence of letters instead of watching for the word itself. You can't even say Assassin. It comes out ******in. That is BS. So if you come across a person that is harassing the crap out of you? Block his text and pray the fight ends soon, because there's nothing else you can do about it. Oh sure, you could report him, a function which apparently only works in selective situations. But I have yet to see that do anything whatsoever, and that leads me to further believe the devs do not care at all.

Needless to say, this is a fantastic game with a fantastic concept that has been completely driven into the ground by obnoxious little brats that are finding and enjoying irritating the crap out of any person that they come across since there are no repercussions whatsoever for being a ♥♥♥♥ in the game. Even League of Legends is more diligent about following their rules, and I don't think I need to expand on that, do I?

TL;DR:
Do you want to play a fun game? This is one.
Do you want to play a fun game with a nice and supportive community that actively want you to keep coming back to enjoy it with them? GOOD FREAKING LUCK FINDING ONE HERE!
For the love of whatever kind of religion or lack thereof you follow, do not play this game. Do not sink hours, weeks, years of your life in what has become a doomed game like I did. Go play something else.

reviewText:
This game is going to be extremely frustrating for brand new players, especially those that leap right into the Daily Mode room the first chance they get. Similar to any fighting game, those that play longer get used to the game's quirks and know exactly how to use them. If this is your first time playing, just TRY TO HAVE FUN. Don't worry about winning, because there is no way you can close the skill gap in a day. Find a hero you love and play the hell out of it.
That being said! I have a few tips for you new players:
1) This is a team game. Throw away that lone wolf mentality. This isn't Smash Brothers.
2) Even if you aren't the best player on your team, try to protect all of your allies equally. If you see a teammate getting attacked, go help them!
3) Items can have a huge effect on the way you play your character. Look for a weapon and set of basic attacks that you like. Any character can wear anyone else's armor. The only thing you can't change is the weapon.
4) If you enter higher level rooms, you'll encounter players who use [Swapping]. This is the rapid changing of your heroes to quickly use powerful skills to rapidly take down an enemy. It takes time and effort to learn, but it isn't hard to do. It can be frustrating to fight against, but any good teammate can stop them mid combo.
5) Again, HAVE FUN. That comes first. Lost Saga has a LOT of modes to play in. Some are 1v1, some are 4v4. Some are against com players and some are like a strange LoL or Dota style with objectives and towers to destroy. This game has variety. Don't force yourself to play a mode you don't like.

That being said, if you want to enjoy this game, treat this game like Dota 2 or LoL. Block almost everyone you meet before they have a chance to open their mouth. reviewText:
Lost Saga is... okay.  It plays alright, with A, S, and D keys acting as combo buttons, with A as jump, S as guard and D as attack, and different combinations of those three keys (A+D, S+D, for example), activates one of four unique skills for each hero.  There are a LOT of heroes in this game, including a few licensed ones, the only problem is they are all locked behind a paywall.  You CAN access heroes free as random drops or by obtaining or purchasing an item with in-game currency that grants you permanent access to a new hero from a short, random list.  However, all other hero purchases with the in-game currency called GP are rentals that las for 2, 4, and 10 hours.  This is rather disappointing because the few heroes I played are fun, but the fact that I either have to pay, re-rent or rely on luck to keep playing them is just a shame.

Lost Saga is lobby-based, so fans of games like DFO will feel comfortable here.  Once you've selected your desired mission or PVP event, you enter a lobby to wait for more players or you can enter a dungeon solor by locking out other players with a password or by using the matuchmaking options.  From there, things are pretty straightforward.  You fight trash mobs, you defeat mini-bosses or towers and doing so turns those into towers for your side, attacking enemies or spawing AI allies to aid you in combat.  It's not a bad idea and it works well.  The gameplay is frenetic, forcing you to think fast, but can mostly be won by simply spamming attack and the occasional powerful skill when it's not on cooldown.  Once you beat the boss, you get a random reward based on performance and then are dropped back into the lobby.  This system isn't as well polished here as it is in other lobby-based MMO's, but the dungeons are much faster, so it doesn't feel so grindy, at least not at first.

A final and minor gripe is the constant pop up balloons from quests and help dialogues that plague the start of this game.    You will click through twenty or more little reward and dialogue balloons just from completing the most pedestrian of tasks, and it gets old.  The writing, which attempts to be clever, is bad and the presentation is just lazy, as all of this dialogue is just pasted on a yellow or blue popup.

reviewText:
It's a trainwreck of errors that ruin an otherwise perfectly good game.

Where to start? Perhaps with the fact that you're charged real money to have a female character. Besides flipping the bird to all you ladies out there, you need to pony up cash to buy anything resembling permanence or customization. The game's defenders will argue that you get all sorts of freebies. They fail to take into account that some of us would like to put together a character from something other than random pieces of garbage strewn about from randomized packs.

Gameplay? Spectacular - once you get past the horrifically overpowered heroes. Don't see them yet? Probably because they're rank-restricted (so only the best people get to crush you). Unless you want to pay cash. Funny how that works. In all honesty, the gameplay is mostly fantastic, save for a few caveats. If you're caught blocking, you're screwed, as the other guy can attack you without any delay, leaving you with no option to fight back. This is a ridiculous failure for a fighting game. The other issue is the sheer number of crowd-control effects that rip away control from your character and, more frustratingly, forcibly reposition your character, often into a pit. How is that fun?

Oh yeah, overpowered heroes. They're out there, the best players have them, and you really don't have much of a hope against them. Expect to be comboed for half your health before falling off the stage, no matter what you do. Game balance was clearly an afterthought for the developers.

This could have been good. Why is the cash portion so forced? Why can't they balance the game properly?

reviewText:
Now lets take an honest look at this game.  I have a little bit of a bias because I have invested a lot of time and money into this game since it came out.  However, that's just the thing.  I have spent money on this game.  Lost Saga and it's players have a VERY heavy pay-to-win mentality.  Now, while having exclusive content isn't always a bad thing in video games, especially free ones, this game (just like every free asian mmo) shows you all the cool things that you can get that can help you but you'll be forced to play the game and get in-game money in order to extend the time limit on the heroes you have.  This can become tedious and set you down a path in which you'll realize that it'd be better to spend money on getting a character without the time limit.  Another thing is the gears.  There are many gears in the game and they can be easily be purchased with in-game currency, however, for a new player who has very little experience with the game, collecting 48k GP is going to be a real struggle.  While you don't need these gears to win, but if you want to make your characters look more appealing as well as have the skills of other characters to help you in battle, you're gonna want to get these gears.

Now, the big thing about this game that makes me tell people that they should avoid it is the community itself.  In my honest opinion, after playing this game since OGP days, it is absolute garbage.  You can't go a minute without seeing someone calling someone out for losing or showing their frustration by rage quitting or something.  It's sad to see that the game's community has not gotten any better.  Trash talk is so common, it makes me mad for all the wrong reasons.  Not because it's rude or anything, but because of how frequent I see it.  Also, if your connection is anything but perfect and you lag, players will relentlessly chew you out for that.

This concludes my Lost Saga review.  Overall, I enjoy the game and enjoy it enough so that I felt like pouring my money into it, but if someone were to ask if they should start playing it, I'd tell them no or that the many mixed reviews this game has already received are all completely justified.

reviewText:
Like some of the reviewers here, I started this game when it was hosted at OGPlanet during 2009. I played for about three years, so please don't be fooled by time I put in steam for this game (although I also did spent considerable time here as well). Overall, during OGPlanet time, I spent about $500 on this game, so you can tell how much I have invested in and how much I liked.

But I cannot recommend to anyone here on Steam to play this game. I will skip usual bread and butter review. Here are the reasons why you should not waste your time (and money) on this game. If you can get past these reasons, then be my guest, download now and enjoy the brawl.

1 - Player base is shrinking. It is harder to find a good game room as your level higher. The game also have skill level system. Which means that you are doing well (Kill/Death ratio), even though your player level is let's say level 1 (they have military style ranking), the game will only find you game room on higher level than level 1 because, well, your skill level is now higher than level 1. Which can give you many problem. You have lesser room to play. You will face higher level player (although not that bad).

2 - Farm, Farm everywhere! What is farm? Well, as you guess it, there are some events going on and most event are based on how long you log in to game and how long you play particular game mode. Sound cool, right? Yes, but the problem is again with player base. I don't understand why these players do what they do. You will not find game room where players are actively, well, playing. They make game room, instead of playing, they just sit there until, fight time counter runs zero. The point of this game is all about fighting and brawling but right now all games are like that. If you don't farm (stay idle), game room host will vote to kick you out. If you just leave your hero idle, the game itself will kick you out for AFK. So in the end, you join a game room to fight but instead you just run around nothing to do. Does that sound fun to you? Not to me.

3 - Game is very latency sensitive. Unless you stay very close to server, you will not get the good ping. Not like other online games like DOTA or LOL, here lag is very visible. Because all your input needs to happen in split second, and if you are lag, the other player suffer! Yes! it's the other way around. Lag wins you. So why does this bad? Well, imagine you lag horribly, you input a punch, it register to another player 10 seconds later. During that time, the other player might have been furiously pressing his punch key to you 100 times but never hit you. He won't be happy, you also won't because all you see is delay after delay. Fighting game with lag is horrible experience.

4 - No strategy, no skill, just spam to win. Although, the game promote creative way to fight each other, here is the a simple truth which has been true since the game come out. Just spam the ♥♥♥♥ out of attack to win. There are some considerable hero that are mostly hated but really just for spamming. One of the example is 'Cyborg' hero, who can just stand behind and spam your attack grenade launchers. Another hero is called 'Gangster' (used to be Mafia back in the days), just spam the gun shooting. Although, there are many ways to counter and win these heroes, in reality, the game is very broken to the point that it is not fun anymore.

5 - The higher the level, the more toxic players you will encounter. Although, this is not just new to online gaming, especially I know in DOTA or LOL, you will find many hostile players, the community in Lost Saga is in a way very immature. If you are older player like me, you will find it annoying or irratitated to the point that you just block the chat to really play the game in peace.

Summary
----------
- Shriking player base.
- No game room, Farm everywhere
- Lag means no fun, and the service does not seem to be better in future
- Spam to win
- Bad community. A lot of 12 years old

Don't play this game.

reviewText:
Z8 what are you doing...THIS GAME IS A HIDDEN GEM! ADVERTISE MORE, GET THE WORD OUT THERE!!! There's a reason it's listed as one of the top games in Korea!
It doesn't look like I've played a lot, but I know what I'm talking about. I've played before Z8 games, all the way back since OGPlanet (a lot of things happened - company transferred, people lost their accounts, used to be really popular. I've come back now that it's stable again, and since it's so so good).
This game is a North American adaptation of Korean Lost Saga. It has a unique hero purchasing system where you can buy heroes for periods of time - 2 hours, 10 hours, 30 hours, permanent, etc. You can use those heroes interchangeably in battle for combos. There are many game modes, but essentially you beat someone by making them lose their health/gear. Each hero has 4 gears that each have a special ability. You can replace some gear by purchasing gears in the shop, excluding weapons. The more you play, the higher rank you get, and the more heroes you unlock. In addition, you can level up heroes and upgrade them to make them stronger. It's a free game, so it's definitely worth playing. You start out with one permanent hero, and soon after you can get another 2 permanent heroes.
Some people call this a pay to win game, and some heroes OP. That's not true. This is a skill-based game. If you're good enough, with ANY hero, you can beat someone. Some heroes are more advantageous than others (premium, legendary heroes especially), but that doesn't necessarily mean you can't win. It's all about which hero suits your style of fighting. Others say that you HAVE to have an input hero to be able to stand a chance - not true either. There are so many playstyles around inputs that the people who say that don't know what theyre talking about. There are some people who've developed infinite combos with some heroes with the help of money and are OP, but Lost Saga is a team based game (mostly). Spending doesn't compensate for skill and teamwork.
The community isn't as big as it was back in OGPlanet, nor is it hacker free, but hackers are kicked as long as you enable auto kick for poor network. It's not a dead community - and it never will be, with the people who've dedicated so much time into this game. There are even tournaments in other countries where it's more popular.
Don't get turned off by some of the text glitches in tutorial and the guide/quests. Z8 is focusing on adding more heroes and events, not getting new players, unfortunately. This game has a unique combat system, it's free, it's easy going, and it's fun. This is the only game I cared enough to do a review for. Try it!

out of playing any shooter with reasonable aiming mechanics.

Lost saga.... Where to begin...

There are many many problems with this game.  It looks good on paper but plays like trash right now.

In this fighting game the cheapest and easiest moves to pull off will allow you to win. Using highly skilled moves, charecters  and combos won't get you as far. Which makes this game quite trashy for a fighter. You are not rewarded for taking the time to become skilled at a character that is very hard to master.

Been playing this since the OGP Beta.

Here are some of the many issues with this game.
- Constant disconnections
- Is not good for your pc will cause BSODs and kernal errors.
- The events revolve around play time lately. Now for the past 2 months there has been dc issues and lag issues. Put 2 and 2 together and you cannot complete any of the events as it resets upon disconnection.
- It is not as P2W like others have stated. They have tons of events to obtain these cash items however you would have to no life it to get anywhere.
- The quality of fights absolutely sucks. Playing Lost Saga is like having a bi-polar girlfriend. You never know what you are going to wake up tomorrow. What new problem will there be with the game?
- In fights half of the time the enemies can hit you , but you can't hit them at all even with large AOE skills and a godly connection and computer.
- Lots of foreigners in this game who are trying to kill it. They have a version of this in their own country or close to it yet they come to wreck LSNA because Z8 does not implement foreign restrictions which was promised earlier by them.
- You can be highly skilled with a character but if the enemy has better gears then you, you are going to lose.
- The community is quite toxic. It is filled with a bunch of sewer people and 10 year old GET REKT ****** children.
- Many people who are trying to play this game right now can't even log in . I don't know why they would want to though considering the quality of this game right now. Which is really sad because it has some great potential . This is the 3rd company Lost Saga has been with.

Always starts off good ut then those in power get greedy and allow foreigners in which bogs down the server and ruins the game for everybody else eventually ending in the games demise.

It is funner than smash bros. Just a shame that it keeps ending up in the hands of people incapable of running it properly.  Oh yes and if you want a premium hero be prepared to spend 20.00.

My advice though would be not to spend a dime on this game until they get the quality under control.

reviewText:
WARNING:  IF YOU HATE TO LOSE, YOU'LL HATE THIS GAME!

Lost Saga is a very fun game, as long as you got an open and competitive mind. You either win a lot, lose a lot or a mix of both. Mainly PVP with a bunch of modes, some PVE and the Plaza where you can just relax and chat or doing optional missions that can gives you some nice stuff if you're lucky. Unlike half the people here leaving hate comments because they can't win, there's many ways to win  even if you lose the match: I'm talking of the Honorable Mentions at the end of each match that grade your performance during battle. These give you bonus GP to use in the market.

Althought Pay to Win concept, there's a lot of quests and events that give you some awesome items or powerful  characters that you would normally have to pay to obtain. Without having to spent a penny, I managed to get 4 permanent characters which 3 of them are girls and another 2 female conversion tickets (Yes, you have to pay to get the female version of a Hero); Along with other permanent  epic and rare armors/weapon/accessories, etc.

You can end up having just as powerful Heros by playing free just as those who purchase OP Heros. The only difference is that they get them faster, but where's the fun in that. Train your Heros, get better and feel proud.

Gameplay wise, it's fast and fluid. Of course a good pc is key here and also a very good internet connection. Like a few mentionned, some people play wireless and got a downright terrible connection, making them hard to kill in a match. Worst case this can happen is during Boss Raid and they're the selected Boss. Each character is unique and play differently. So many styles to choose from. When you're used to them, you can purchase or obtain various special equipments to equip them depending on your preference. 1 hero could combine the speciality of 3 others heros if you wanted.

Try it for yourself before listening to complainers. You'll have ton of good time.
